content.body: Caridy’s `Module` object is very similar to the `ModuleInstance` you proposed at the last plenary. The big difference is that dynamic import kicks off the loader / linker, and that uses the import hook to discover the linkage. It has the nice property that a single hook can be used for both static and dynamic import.
content.formatted_body: Caridy’s Module object is very similar to the ModuleInstance you proposed at the last plenary. The big difference is that dynamic import kicks off the loader / linker, and that uses the import hook to discover the linkage. It has the nice property that a single hook can be used for both static and dynamic import.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Caridy’s `Module` object is very similar to the `ModuleInstance` you proposed at the last plenary. The big difference is that dynamic import kicks off the loader / linker, and that uses the import hook to discover the linkage. It has the nice property that a single hook can be used for both static and dynamic import.

Caridy’s Module object is very similar to the ModuleInstance you proposed at the last plenary. The big difference is that dynamic import kicks off the loader / linker, and that uses the import hook to discover the linkage. It has the nice property that a single hook can be used for both static and dynamic import.

content.body:
> <@guybedford:matrix.org> @littledan thanks for the feedback, we see module reflection as laying down an approach that asset reflection and deferred execution can follow in, as opposed to the original more abstract view of a generical mechanic. Trying to be practical and use case focused while treating generalization as a possibility but not to over-generalize. We are keen to see asset references and deferred module loading move forward, we are just trying to focus our efforts in a way that keeps scope clear in the staging process. We currently are underspecifying what exactly the shape of the reflection object is though, and treating this as a detail to be refined as opposed to prescribing it at this point. The way we do this for now is to entirely delegate it to a host hook, then the hope for Stage 3 would be to follow-up with an exact definition for JS that will hopefully have progressed by then. We need the host hook regardless for Wasm though.

Yes, going incrementally via the stage process seems generally good, but could you say more about why you decided to make the cut here exactly? I mean, presumably the host hook underspecification approach you describe would work just as well for asset references. Are there particular anticipated sources of complexity from asset references that you see as simpler for module reflection?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @guybedford:matrix.org
@littledan thanks for the feedback, we see module reflection as laying down an approach that asset reflection and deferred execution can follow in, as opposed to the original more abstract view of a generical mechanic. Trying to be practical and use case focused while treating generalization as a possibility but not to over-generalize. We are keen to see asset references and deferred module loading move forward, we are just trying to focus our efforts in a way that keeps scope clear in the staging process. We currently are underspecifying what exactly the shape of the reflection object is though, and treating this as a detail to be refined as opposed to prescribing it at this point. The way we do this for now is to entirely delegate it to a host hook, then the hope for Stage 3 would be to follow-up with an exact definition for JS that will hopefully have progressed by then. We need the host hook regardless for Wasm though.
Yes, going incrementally via the stage process seems generally good, but could you say more about why you decided to make the cut here exactly? I mean, presumably the host hook underspecification approach you describe would work just as well for asset references. Are there particular anticipated sources of complexity from asset references that you see as simpler for module reflection?

content.body:
> <@kriskowal:matrix.org> My feeling is that trusting the sender and receiver to have identical importHook behavior is possible but fragile. But, if we have blocks, static blocks, `Module` and `ModuleSource` to work with, I think that the ecosystem will have everything it needs to come up with more sensible protocols for sending modules to workers.

In the web, I’m not sure if we need any “trusting” here: the hooks simply are the same for native modules, and maybe we should just throw a DataCloneError if you try to serialize a Module with any other importHook
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @kriskowal:matrix.org
My feeling is that trusting the sender and receiver to have identical importHook behavior is possible but fragile. But, if we have blocks, static blocks, Module and ModuleSource to work with, I think that the ecosystem will have everything it needs to come up with more sensible protocols for sending modules to workers.
In the web, I’m not sure if we need any “trusting” here: the hooks simply are the same for native modules, and maybe we should just throw a DataCloneError if you try to serialize a Module with any other importHook

content.body:
> <@kriskowal:matrix.org> That is to say, I predict that `worker.import(module {})` will look good in examples but will otherwise have limited utility. But, that’s okay with me.

Well… this is much of the stated motivation of the proposal that Surma and I presented to committee and that the committee agreed to Stage 2 on. I am surprised to see so much skepticism on this point and interesting in understanding more about why you feel this way; I wonder what went wrong in communication that we didn’t uncover this disagreement sooner.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @kriskowal:matrix.org
That is to say, I predict that worker.import(module {}) will look good in examples but will otherwise have limited utility. But, that’s okay with me.

I am surprised to see so much skepticism on this point and interesting in understanding more about why you feel this way; I wonder what went wrong in communication that we didn’t uncover this disagreement sooner.

content.body: Wasm itself prohibits module import cycles, but the Wasm ESM integration proposal is designed to permit them between JS and Wasm… but maybe it does so in too flaky of a way

I guess now that I hear more about how the caching for the import happens within the Module, rather than a single Module producing a separate instance somewhere else… I understand why you all have been calling this construct ModuleInstance over the years
content.formatted_body: I guess now that I hear more about how the caching for the import happens within the Module, rather than a single Module producing a separate instance somewhere else… I understand why you all have been calling this construct ModuleInstance over the years

content.body:
I'm re-reading the slides Kris Kowal presented yesterday, and I have a question.

In the example with a custom module source, I see that the `initialize` method receives `importMeta`. Does it also receive `importHook`? I'm trying do understand if/how Source Text Static Module Records could be expressed in terms of Virtual Static Module Records. For example, how could I create a custom module source that uses my own ecmascript engine and delegates module loading to the ecmascript host it's running in?
content.formatted_body:
I'm re-reading the slides Kris Kowal presented yesterday, and I have a question.

In the example with a custom module source, I see that the initialize method receives importMeta. Does it also receive importHook? I'm trying do understand if/how Source Text Static Module Records could be expressed in terms of Virtual Static Module Records. For example, how could I create a custom module source that uses my own ecmascript engine and delegates module loading to the ecmascript host it's running in?

I'm re-reading the slides Kris Kowal presented yesterday, and I have a question.

For example, how could I create a custom module source that uses my own ecmascript engine and delegates module loading to the ecmascript host it's running in?

I'm re-reading the slides Kris Kowal presented yesterday, and I have a question.

In the example with a custom module source, I see that the initialize method receives importMeta. Does it also receive importHook? I'm trying do understand if/how Source Text Static Module Records could be expressed in terms of Virtual Static Module Records. For example, how could I create a custom module source that uses my own ecmascript engine and delegates module loading to the ecmascript host it's running in?

content.body: I think the answer is yes. JavaScript module sources can be virtualized. It’s also possible to implement `ModuleSource` as an object that satisfies the virtual module source protocol. But, I imagine that would come at a performance cost that isn’t acceptable.
content.formatted_body: I think the answer is yes. JavaScript module sources can be virtualized. It’s also possible to implement ModuleSource as an object that satisfies the virtual module source protocol. But, I imagine that would come at a performance cost that isn’t acceptable.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I think the answer is yes. JavaScript module sources can be virtualized. It’s also possible to implement `ModuleSource` as an object that satisfies the virtual module source protocol. But, I imagine that would come at a performance cost that isn’t acceptable.

I think the answer is yes. JavaScript module sources can be virtualized. It’s also possible to implement ModuleSource as an object that satisfies the virtual module source protocol. But, I imagine that would come at a performance cost that isn’t acceptable.

content.body: For JavaScript to JavaScript bindings, I think engines are free to implement linkage as literal pointers to shared slots. Through the virtual module source protocol, reading and writing bindings would have to pass through the module imports namespace exotic object, which would be slow on top of slow.

Through the virtual module source protocol, reading and writing bindings would have to pass through the module imports namespace exotic object, which would be slow on top of slow.

content.body: littledan: it's more about handling the consensus process itself, we don't want to try to do more than absolutely necessary to avoid unnecessary frictions. But yes asset references themselves should be relatively simple to spec and we are aiming to design host invariants that can work with that as well. The shape of the asset object may or may not be specified in ECMA-262, I'd personally like to see it in EMCA-262.

content.body: Daniel Ehrenberg: I don’t mean to communicate an absolutist stance. Even locally, there’s no guarantee that a module graph is consistent over time. But, on one extreme, sending a module to a worker is maximally fragile and on the other minimally fragile. I believe you and I agree that we’re converging on a foundation that is sufficient for implementing either extreme. And I think that we also agree that sending a worker and depending on out-of-band coordination of importHooks is a maximally fragile solution on that spectrum. And emphatically, I personally don’t object.

I believe you and I agree that we’re converging on a foundation that is sufficient for implementing either extreme. And I think that we also agree that sending a worker and depending on out-of-band coordination of importHooks is a maximally fragile solution on that spectrum. And emphatically, I personally don’t object.

content.body: * Daniel Ehrenberg: I don’t mean to communicate an absolutist stance. Even locally, there’s no guarantee that a module graph is consistent over time. But, on one extreme, sending a module to a worker is maximally fragile and on the other (sending a module with an RPC/IPC handle to the original loader) minimally fragile. I believe you and I agree that we’re converging on a foundation that is sufficient for implementing either extreme. And I think that we also agree that sending a worker and depending on out-of-band coordination of importHooks is a maximally fragile solution on that spectrum. And emphatically, I personally don’t object.

content.body: Although we'll be able to enforce some invariants by construction or through checks: if we ship a loader API, it will be possible to use importHook badly/confusingly, just as it is possible to use Proxy and even Object.defineProperty badly/confusingly today. These misuses would lack some desired properties but still be deemed OK by the system. I don't think that's fatal.

content.body: I have a 90' slot to talk about compartments that I was thinking to repurpose as a Module Harmony preso, in the same vein as the last two presentations, if folks here are alright with me representing us collectively.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I have a 90' slot to talk about compartments that I was thinking to repurpose as a Module Harmony preso, in the same vein as the last two presentations, if folks here are alright with me representing us collectively.

content.body: That is, here’s a strawman / holistic vision and here are some of the open questions.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That is, here’s a strawman / holistic vision and here are some of the open questions.

content.body: I think that leaves a decent chunk of time for discussion, but it’s not like I’ve ever finished a preso.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think that leaves a decent chunk of time for discussion, but it’s not like I’ve ever finished a preso.

content.body: I think that, in this upcoming meeting, we aren't yet ready to present ourselves as a group beyond "we've been meeting and discussing these proposals"; it's premature to announce a holistic vision of the group, as opposed to just certain members of the group
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think that, in this upcoming meeting, we aren't yet ready to present ourselves as a group beyond "we've been meeting and discussing these proposals"; it's premature to announce a holistic vision of the group, as opposed to just certain members of the group

content.body: Sure, so I should stick to, here’s where I think we’re headed with compartments.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Sure, so I should stick to, here’s where I think we’re headed with compartments.

content.body: I don’t think that precludes “how this might relate to blocks, deferred execution, and module reflection” but I agree that it’s too early to claim I’ve internalized all the champions’ perspectives.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I don’t think that precludes “how this might relate to blocks, deferred execution, and module reflection” but I agree that it’s too early to claim I’ve internalized all the champions’ perspectives.

content.body: yes, let's leave it to proposal champions to decide which open questions they want to bring to the committee. For example, I'd be a little uncomfortable having an all-committee debate on whether module blocks are ModuleSource or Module, at least just right now
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: yes, let's leave it to proposal champions to decide which open questions they want to bring to the committee. For example, I'd be a little uncomfortable having an all-committee debate on whether module blocks are ModuleSource or Module, at least just right now

content.body: I don’t feel like I’m far off, but I wouldn’t presume.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I don’t feel like I’m far off, but I wouldn’t presume.

content.body: Oh, indeed. That would not be a fun conversation.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Oh, indeed. That would not be a fun conversation.

content.body: yeah I trust that you have a good understanding of at least Caridy's and my views on that particular question, but it's more that, we can let the individual champion decide when to encourage a large group discussion to draw a conclusion.

content.body: Caridy has a good intuition about what plays well at plenary, I think. I’ll listen harder for the next couple weeks.

content.body: simply, there is no agreement on the foundations yet, so i agree with dan's intuition to not present as a group nor open the floor to questions like "is this (e.g. ModuleSource) a good foundation"

content.body: The compartments proposal does have an answer for virtualization that could be served a la carte.

content.body: Caridy’s subset does not include virtualization at all, and I think we will want to lead with that.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Caridy’s subset does not include virtualization at all, and I think we will want to lead with that.

content.body: But module source virtualization is the key to unlocking many experiments in user code. Currently, we use this feature in Endo to create a bridge back to CommonJS that is coherent with bundling and other tools.

content.body: Reifying execution contexts can also be served a la carte.
